title: 109_s4107
content: The "College Opportunity Tax Credit Act of 2006" allows for a College Opportunity Tax Credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This credit replaces the Hope Scholarship Credit and the Lifetime Learning Credit with new credit amounts for eligible students. The College Opportunity Tax Credit Act of 2006 introduces the College Opportunity Credit, replacing previous credits. Section 25A is amended in the Internal Revenue Code. The College Opportunity Tax Credit Act of 2006 introduces the College Opportunity Credit, amending section 25A of the Internal Revenue Code to adjust the eligible student credit amount and increase the applicable limit from 2 to 3. Additionally, the credit is made refundable. The College Opportunity Tax Credit Act of 2006 introduces the College Opportunity Credit, amending section 25A of the Internal Revenue Code to adjust the eligible student credit amount and increase the applicable limit from 2 to 3. The aggregate credits allowed under subpart C shall be increased by the amount of the credit which would be allowed under this section without regard to certain limitations. The College Opportunity Tax Credit Act of 2006 amends section 25A of the Internal Revenue Code to increase the eligible student credit amount from 2 to 4 years. It eliminates the limitation on the first 2 years of postsecondary education and makes conforming amendments. The College Opportunity Tax Credit Act of 2006 amends section 25A of the Internal Revenue Code to increase the eligible student credit amount from 2 to 4 years and makes conforming amendments to subsection (b) and (c) of the Code. The College Opportunity Tax Credit Act of 2006 expands the eligible student credit amount to 4 years and adjusts the part-time, graduate, and other student credit amount based on qualified tuition and related expenses paid during the taxable year. The applicable limit for any taxable year is 3 times the dollar amount in effect for that year. Special rules exclude expenses for eligible students with a credit and allow expenses for job skills courses. The dollar limitation on the amount of credit under subsection (a)(2) is subject to inflation adjustments, increasing the $1,000 amounts for eligible educational expenses. The text discusses adjustments to the dollar limitation on the credit for eligible educational expenses under subsection (a)(2) for the calendar year in which the taxable year begins. It also mentions rounding rules for adjusted amounts and a conforming amendment to the code. Additionally, it addresses the credit allowed against the alternative minimum tax. The amendment limits the credit for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2006, based on the amount of tax and adjusts the Code accordingly.
